moves.1... c6: I always hate it, when they do that; avoiding the question... in stead of playing 1. ... e5 or c5, to at least create some counterplay, they choose to bury themselves in closed positions, like French or Caro-Kann... I usually break them open as soon as possible...
moves.2. d4 d5: c4 is an option here, but not for the faint hearted...
moves.3. e5 Bf5 4. Bd3: Caro-Kann Advance variation... Nf6 is blocked, and we control the center...
moves.4... Bxd3 5. Qxd3 e6 6. Nf3 c5 7. dxc5 B: Qb5+, Nd7, Qxb7, Rb8, Qa6, Ne7, 0-0, soon leads to an equal position...
moves.8... Nc6 9. Nbd2 Nge7 10. Nb3 Bb6 11. Bg: so far, black has maintained a fairly equal position, and decides to liberate his pieces... but he underestimates whites' possibilities... of course, for instance Nc6 was way safer...
moves.21. Nxe6: like a bolt from the sky...
moves.21... fxe6: not better was Re8, Nfd4, Bxd4, Rxd4, Qc7, and take the loss...
moves.22. Qxg6 Rde8 23. Nd4 Bxd4 24. Rxd4 Qc7: another bad choice; black is choking the King... best was d4, Rxd4, to postpone building up tensions...
moves.28. Reh3 Qd7: the final mistake; only after Qxe5 at some point during g2-g4-g5, black can keep defending this on f6/f7...
moves.29. Rh4xh6+ gxh6 30. Qf6+:
it is over, after Rgg7 (otherwise mate on h6), Qxh6+, Kg8, Qh8+, Kf7, Rf3+, Kg6, Rf6+ (thanks to e5), Kg5, f4+, Kg4, Qh3 and mate...

so black resigned...
